block.p: After weeks of negotiations, House Republican leaders agreed to language that would weaken the economic embargo against Cuba for the first time in four decades. The bill, pushed by Representative George W. Nethercutt Jr., a Washington Republican, would permit the direct sale of food to Cuba, similar to a policy allowing the sale of medicine.

After weeks of negotiations, House Republican leaders agreed to language that would weaken the economic embargo against Cuba for the first time in four decades. The bill, pushed by Representative George W. Nethercutt Jr., a Washington Republican, would permit the direct sale of food to Cuba, similar to a policy allowing the sale of medicine.

But the legislation, designed to benefit agribusiness and to shore up Mr. Nethercutt's re-election chances, is so loaded down with restrictions that it is more a symbolic step toward normalizing Cuban-American relations than it is a boon to farmers.
